title: A novel DFNA9 mutation in the vWFA2 domain of COCH alters a conserved cysteine residue and intrachain disulfide bond formation resulting in progressive hearing loss and site‐specific vestibular and central oculomotor dysfunction

text:
**AssayGeneralClass**: BAO:0002424 western blot

**AssayMaterialUsed**: CLO:0001230 HEK293 cells

**AssayDescription**: Media from cultured HEK293 cells transiently transfected with HA-tagged human COCH constructs were analyzed by western blot following reducing gel electrophoresis to assess steady-state levels of the protein and disulfide bond formation.

**AssayReadOutDescription**: Protein band size and intensity

**AssayRange**: Presence, absence, increased abundance, or decreased abundance of full length cochlin at ~60 kDa and presence/absence of smaller sized cochlin doublet representing small processed, secreted isoforms (~45 kDa and ~50 kDa)

**AssayNormalRange**: Presence of full-length cochlin (~60 kDa) and smaller isoforms (~45 kDa and ~50 kDa)

**AssayAbnormalRange**: Absence or decreased abundance of full-length cochlin or smaller isoforms

**AssayIndeterminateRange**: Not reported

**ValidationControlPathogenic**: 0

**ValidationControlBenign**: 0

**Replication**: Not reported

**StatisticalAnalysisDescription**: Not reported

**PValueThreshold**: Not reported

selector.exact:
Expression Constructs and Transient Transfections
            
            Human wild‐type COCH  cDNA was cloned previously [Robertson et al., 2003] into a modified form of pcDNA3 that permits expression of polypeptides with three C‐terminal hemagglutinin (HA) tags. The c.1625G > T point mutation was introduced using QuikChange (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA). In addition to the wild‐type and p.C542F COCH  constructs, two previously characterized COCH  mutants (p.P51S, p.G88E) were also transfected into human embryonic kidney 293T cells as described before [Robertson et al., 2003].
            
            
         
         
         
            
             Immunoprecipitation and Western Blot Analysis
            
            Conditioned media (300 µl) from transfected cells were incubated with anti‐HA (clone HA.11) bound to beads (Covance, Richmond, CA) for 2–4 hr at 4°C. Beads were washed 3–5× in PBS, centrifuged and lysed by heating at 95–100°C for 5 min in SDS–PAGE buffer without β‐ME (for non‐reducing conditions). For reducing conditions, β‐ME was subsequently added to aliquots of both the cell lysates and immunoprecipitated proteins from the media. Proteins were separated by SDS gel electrophoresis using 10% and 4%–12% polyacrylamide gradient gels and transferred to Immobilon‐P (Millipore, Bedford, MA) membranes using a wet transfer apparatus (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA). Membranes were incubated with mouse anti‐HA monoclonal antibody (clone HA.11) and autoluminograms were prepared as reported previously [Robertson et al., 2003].

title: A novel DFNA9 mutation in the vWFA2 domain of COCH alters a conserved cysteine residue and intrachain disulfide bond formation resulting in progressive hearing loss and site‐specific vestibular and central oculomotor dysfunction

text:
**AssayGeneralClass**: BAO:0002424 western blot

**AssayMaterialUsed**: CLO:0001230 HEK293 cells

**AssayDescription**: Media from cultured HEK293 cells transiently transfected with HA-tagged human COCH constructs were analyzed by western blot following non-reducing gel electrophoresis to assess steady-state levels of the protein and efficiency of post-translational proteolytic processing.

**AssayReadOutDescription**: Protein band size and intensity

**AssayRange**: Presence, absence, increased abundance, or decreased abundance of full length cochlin at ~60 kDa and presence/absence of smaller sized cochlin doublet representing small processed, secreted isoforms (~45 kDa and ~50 kDa)

**AssayNormalRange**: Presence of full-length cochlin (~60 kDa) and smaller isoforms (~45 kDa and ~50 kDa)

**AssayAbnormalRange**: Absence or decreased abundance of full-length cochlin or smaller isoforms

**AssayIndeterminateRange**: Not reported

**ValidationControlPathogenic**: 0

**ValidationControlBenign**: 0

**Replication**: Not reported

**StatisticalAnalysisDescription**: Not reported

**PValueThreshold**: Not reported

selector.exact:
Expression Constructs and Transient Transfections
            
            Human wild‐type COCH  cDNA was cloned previously [Robertson et al., 2003] into a modified form of pcDNA3 that permits expression of polypeptides with three C‐terminal hemagglutinin (HA) tags. The c.1625G > T point mutation was introduced using QuikChange (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA). In addition to the wild‐type and p.C542F COCH  constructs, two previously characterized COCH  mutants (p.P51S, p.G88E) were also transfected into human embryonic kidney 293T cells as described before [Robertson et al., 2003].
            
            
         
         
         
            
             Immunoprecipitation and Western Blot Analysis
            
            Conditioned media (300 µl) from transfected cells were incubated with anti‐HA (clone HA.11) bound to beads (Covance, Richmond, CA) for 2–4 hr at 4°C. Beads were washed 3–5× in PBS, centrifuged and lysed by heating at 95–100°C for 5 min in SDS–PAGE buffer without β‐ME (for non‐reducing conditions). For reducing conditions, β‐ME was subsequently added to aliquots of both the cell lysates and immunoprecipitated proteins from the media. Proteins were separated by SDS gel electrophoresis using 10% and 4%–12% polyacrylamide gradient gels and transferred to Immobilon‐P (Millipore, Bedford, MA) membranes using a wet transfer apparatus (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA). Membranes were incubated with mouse anti‐HA monoclonal antibody (clone HA.11) and autoluminograms were prepared as reported previously [Robertson et al., 2003].

title: A novel DFNA9 mutation in the vWFA2 domain of COCH alters a conserved cysteine residue and intrachain disulfide bond formation resulting in progressive hearing loss and site‐specific vestibular and central oculomotor dysfunction

selector.suffix: mutation in exon 12 of COCH  th

title: A novel DFNA9 mutation in the vWFA2 domain of COCH alters a conserved cysteine residue and intrachain disulfide bond formation resulting in progressive hearing loss and site‐specific vestibular and central oculomotor dysfunction

text:
**Gene**: COCH

**Disease**: Autosomal dominant nonsyndromic deafness

**MONDO**: 0019587

**InheritancePattern**: HP:0000006 autosomal dominant

selector.exact: Mutations within the COCH  gene (encoding the cochlin protein) lead to auditory and vestibular impairment in the DFNA9  disorder. In this study, we describe the genetic mapping of progressive autosomal dominant sensorineural hearing loss first affecting high‐frequency auditory thresholds within a human pedigree to the long arm of chromosome 14 in band q12.

text:
**AssayResult**: Expected ~60 kDa band and expected ~50 kDa band both appear larger in size (possibly due to altered migration pattern), while ~45 kDa band is not visible. ~50 kDa band also appears decreased in abundance compared to wild type COCH.

**AssayResultAssertion**: Abnormal

selector.exact: Under non‐reducing conditions, the p.C542F mutant cochlin migrates more slowly than the wild‐type, p.P51S, and p.G88E cochlin mutants
